newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: U.S. CAUTIONS S.AFRICA AGAINST EU FREE TRADE PACT.
newsitem.headline: U.S. CAUTIONS S.AFRICA AGAINST EU FREE TRADE PACT.

text.p: A U.S. senior government official warned South Africa and other regional states on Thursday against seeking a free trade agreement with the European Union (EU), saying this was against the spirit of free trade with all.
Lauri J. Fitz-Pegado, Assistant Secretary and Director-General of the U.S. Commercial Services, was speaking at a Southern Africa Trade and Investment Summit.

She told delegates that if the region remained committed to structural changes to enhance both domestic and external trade, it would attract vital foreign investment necessary for long-term economic growth.

"In doing so, I urge them to exercise caution and to avoid short-term solutions, such as the proposed agreement (by South Africa) with the European Union, that raise questions of WTO (World Trade Organisation) compatibility and that could discriminate against other trading partners," she said.

Pretoria plans to negotiate a free trade agreement with the EU, but says it must answer regional anxieties by ensuring the interests of its partners in the 12-nation Southern African Development Community (SADC) are not compromised by such a pact.
SADC consists of Angola, Botswana, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Lesotho, Tanzania, South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Fitz-Pegado also told the two-day Harare conference, ending on Thursday, that as well as marketing themselves internationally, Sub-Saharan African states must boost intra-regional trade, currently estimated at seven percent of their total GDP compared to about 60 percent in the EU.
